text: What's up? This is Alex, DJ Couchking, and welcome to another video in my beginner series
on Ableton Live 10. In this video, I'm going to show you how to get started recording and editing
audio inside Ableton Live. I'm going to break this video down into four parts. In the first part,
I'll tell you everything you need to follow along with this tutorial. In the second part,
we'll set up the software for recording. In part three, we will record some audio. And in part four,
I'll show you the basic editing functions inside Ableton Live. The first thing you'll need is some
kind of input source. This could be a microphone, a DJ setup like the one behind me, a guitar,
a keyboard, whatever. You just need something to actually record. Next, make sure you have all the
appropriate cables to connect your input source to your computer or interface. Finally, you'll
need some sort of input to your computer. This could be the built-in microphone or the built-in
input on your computer, but I would highly recommend getting an external audio interface.
Something like this guy, the Focusrite 2i2. These are great little recording interfaces,
and they're very affordable. I'll put a link to this and some affordable microphones in the
description below. Now that we've got all our hardware ready, let's jump into the software.
All right, so I've opened up Ableton Live on my computer. Let's set up our DAW for recording. For
this tutorial, we will be using the arrangement view. Press the tab key on your keyboard or click
the horizontal lines on the top right to switch views. New live sets are created with two audio
and two MIDI tracks. We will only need one audio track for this, so let's delete the others by
clicking on the labels on the right-hand side and pressing the delete key. Next, we will need to
make sure that we have the right input set up in our audio preferences. If you're on PC, click on
options and go to preferences. If you're on a Mac, this will be under the menu called live. Once we
have the preferences open, make sure you click on the audio tab. Under audio device, make sure your
audio interface is selected. If you're on Windows, also make sure that the driver type is set to ASIO.
Now we can click on input config. From here, we can activate all the different inputs that we'll
be using. Your interface may have less or more inputs than mine. Whichever input you plugged
your input source into, make sure that that's activated. If you're not sure, just go ahead and
turn all these on. It's really not going to hurt anything. Once you're done here, just press okay
and close out of the preferences window. Now that our audio preferences are set up for recording,
let's set up our audio track. On the right-hand side, in the middle of our channel strip settings,
you'll see three drop-down boxes. This is your input and output routing for each of the channels
inside Ableton Live. In this tutorial, we will only be recording one source, but if you're recording
multiple microphones, multiple instruments, or just multiple of anything, just repeat the following
steps multiple times and you should be just fine. I'm going to leave external input selected in the
top box and then choose the input that I've plugged my microphone into on the bottom box.
If you talk into it, you should see some activity going on on the meters. As you can see, mine is
plugged into input number nine, so I'm going to click on that right there. Next, take a look at
the monitoring section directly below this. By default, this is set to off. The monitoring section
allows you to listen to whatever you're recording through the software. If this is set to off, the
software is expecting you to be listening through your interface or mixing board. If your interface
does not have direct monitoring, set this to auto and it will allow you to monitor your input. I'm
going to leave this set to off since I'm monitoring through my interface. This setup will be different
for everyone, so if you're not sure what to do here, refer to the manual for your interface.
But if you want to be able to hear effects such as reverbs, compressors, delays, any of that,
then you're going to have to monitor through the software, which means that you'll have to
have this set to auto. And if you click in, this means that you want to listen to that input all
the time, and I don't recommend this unless you're doing live looping or live performance.
Now that our routing is set up, let's record arm the track by clicking the record arm button on
the far right of the channel. Our track is now set up to record. If you look up in the top screen,
you will notice that there are two record buttons. We've got a hollered out one and then one that is
filled in solid black. We're only going to worry about this one that is filled in solid black.
We're in the arrangement view, and this is our arrangement record. The other one is for recording
into the session view, which we'll cover in another video. Before you record, check the metronome and
quantize settings over here in the top left. If you're not sure what these do, refer to my last
video in this series where I give a complete overview of the Ableton Live software. And I'm
going to turn my metronome off, make sure there's no count in, and then just make sure there's no
quantize because I'm just recording a voice over here. Now we can go ahead and hit the
arrangement record button to start recording. Hi, my name is Alex, and I'm recording in Ableton Live.
Now that we've recorded some audio to work with, let's move on to editing. So by default,
Ableton will have the musical grid active. You can view the grid settings by right clicking and
scrolling down to the bottom of the context menu. If you're recording music, this is a great way to
keep your edits in time with the click. In this case, I'm just recording a voice over,
so I'm going to make sure that this is turned off. So I'm going to double click stop to go back to
the beginning here. And then I'm going to just edit this so that my voice starts playing right
at the beginning. Right now you can see there's a little bit of a delay. Hi, my name is Alex,
and I'm recording in Ableton Live. Now there's a few different ways we can do this. I can either
just come up here to the top left of the label and grab it and scooch it right up to the beginning
there. I can hover over the middle of the clip and highlight a section and then delete it.
Or I can double click on the clip label and open up the clip editor. I'm not going to go over all
the settings in the clip editor in this video. We will cover all of it over the course of the
remaining videos. These two arrows above the waveform show the start, end, and loop points.
If I grab the bottom arrow and move it, this will adjust the start point in the arrangement
view above. As you can see, when I move this, it moves the clip up here up top. So if I snug
this right up against it, and also if you're working with the grid off, they are separate.
So make sure that you turn the grid off down here also. Otherwise, that can be kind of annoying.
Everything I mentioned before applies to adjusting the end point of a clip also.
So if I want to trim the end of this, I can grab this arrow over here and just move that.
Or I can come up here and grab the label and adjust it there, or highlight and delete.
A bunch of different ways to do it. I kind of like editing things down here, so I'm going to
go ahead and grab this and move it and trim that up. Down here you can also adjust the level
of the recorded audio. You can also do things like warp and transpose, but we're going to cover
those in other videos. It's just too much for one video. The last thing I want to talk about is
adding fades to your audio. To do this, we're just going to hover over the middle of the clip,
and you will see these four squares pop up. The top square is to add a fade in or fade out
to the audio, and then the bottom square adjusts where that fade starts or ends. To add a cross
fade to multiple clips, highlight a section of both of the audio clips, right click, and click
on create cross fade. Thanks for checking this video out. If you have any questions for me,
feel free to leave a comment. I try to get back to everyone as soon as I can. If you like this
video and you learned something from it, make sure to hit that like button, hit the subscribe button,
and turn on notifications so you can get all of the videos in this series as soon as they come out.
Thanks for watching. Peace.
